an6.38:1.1: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
an6.38:1.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
an6.38:1.3: “Master Gotama, this is my doctrine and view:
an6.38:1.4: One does not act of one’s own volition, nor does one act of another’s volition.”
an6.38:1.5: “Well, brahmin, I’ve never seen or heard of anyone holding such a doctrine or view.
an6.38:1.6: How on earth can someone who comes and goes on his own say that
an6.38:1.7: one does not act of one’s own volition, nor does one act of another’s volition?
an6.38:2.1: What do you think, brahmin, is there an element of initiative?”
an6.38:2.3: “Since this is so, do we find sentient beings who initiate activity?”
an6.38:2.5: “Since there is an element of initiative, and sentient beings who initiate activity are found, sentient beings act of their own volition or that of another.
an6.38:3.1: What do you think, brahmin, is there an element of persistence …
an6.38:3.7: “Since this is so, do we find sentient beings who have energy?”
an6.38:3.9: “Since there is an element of energy, and sentient beings who have energy are found, sentient beings act of their own volition or that of another.
an6.38:4.1: Well, brahmin, I’ve never seen or heard of anyone holding such a doctrine or view.
an6.38:4.2: How on earth can someone who comes and goes on his own say that
an6.38:4.3: one does not act of one’s own volition, nor does one act of another’s volition?”
an6.38:5.2: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
